model

Class SearchArea

  • java.lang.Object
    • model.SearchArea

  • public final class SearchArea
extends java.lang.Object
    An area to be searched by some search algorithm.

    A search area is a 2-dimensional grid of nodes of a given width and height. One node is designated as a start node, and one node is designated as a finish node.

    A search are is constructed according to the search algorithm to be used. This is because the nodes require different state (fields) and behavior (methods) based on which algorithm is used.

    Author:
    Ken Norman

    • Constructor Detail

      • SearchArea

        public SearchArea(int width,
          int height,
          AlgorithmType type)
        Create a new 2-dimensional search area of given width and height. All nodes are initially 'empty' (i.e., not any of the following: start location, finish location, or obstacle.
        Parameters:
        width - The number of nodes in the 'x' dimension.
        height - The number of nodes in the 'y' dimension.
        type - The type of search algorithm being used to search (e.g., A*, DFS, BFS, etc.).

    • Method Detail

      • initialize

        private void initialize()
        Generate the search area.

      • addObstacle

        public boolean addObstacle(int x0,
                  int y0,
                  int x1,
                  int y1)
        Adds an obstacle to the search area. An obstacle is a line from a starting point (x0, y0) to an ending point (x1, y1), inclusive.

        This method employs the Bresenham's line algorithm to determine which nodes are to be designated as obstacle nodes.

        Parameters:
        x0 - The x coordinate of the starting point.
        y0 - The y coordinate of the starting point.
        x1 - The x coordinate of the ending point.
        y1 - The y coordinate of the ending point.
        Returns:
        true if the obstacle was added
        false in either or both of these cases:
        • any part of the line is outside the search area
        • the line overlaps the start node or the finish node (or both)
        See Also:
        Bresenham's_line_algorithm

      • getNode

        public Node getNode(int x,
           int y)
        Parameters:
        x - The x coordinate.
        y - The y coordinate.
        Returns:
        The Node object at the (x, y) coordinate if it is contained in the search area; null otherwise.

      • getNode

        public Node getNode(java.awt.Point p)
        A convenience method for getting a node using a Point to represent its (x, y) coordinate.
        Parameters:
        p - A Point object representing the (x, y) coordinate of a Node
        Returns:
        true if the point is contained in the search area
        false otherwise
        See Also:

      • getNeighbors

        public java.util.Map<Direction,Node> getNeighbors(Node aNode)

        Returns:
        A Map containing the non-obstacle neighbors of a particular node.
        • Key: the direction from the current node ( aNode) to the neighbor node.
        • Value: the neighbor node.

      • getWalkableNeighbors

        public java.util.Map<Direction,Node> getWalkableNeighbors(Node aNode,
                                                 boolean cuttingCornersAllowed)
        Finds the set of walkable neighbors around a given node.

        In the diagrams below, [N] is the node being inspected for whether its neighbors are traversable, X is an obstacle node, ? is a node which may or may not be traversable directly from [N], and ! is a node which is never traversable. 

            Case 1          Case 2
 ┌───┬───┬───┐   ┌───┬───┬───┐
 │   │   │ ? │   │   │ X │ ! │
 ├───┼───┼───┤   ├───┼───┼───┤
 │   │[N]│ X │   │   │[N]│ X │
 ├───┼───┼───┤   ├───┼───┼───┤
 │   │   │ ? │   │   │   │   │
 └───┴───┴───┘   └───┴───┴───┘

        Explanation of the two cases:

        1. If the cuttingCornersAllowed flag is true, then the two ? nodes are traversable from node N; if false, they are not traversable.
        2. The ! node is never traversable from node N (this is equivalent to walking through a wall).
        Parameters:
        aNode - The node around which to find neighbor nodes.
        cuttingCornersAllowed - A flag to indicate whether or not the solution path may traverse diagonally past an obstacle node.
        Returns:
        The Map containing the traversable nodes around aNode .

      • print

        public void print()
        Prints the search area as a grid, and populates it with the start node, finish node, all obstacle nodes, and the solution path.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Output a string representation of the search area.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        A string of the form: 
         W: <width>, H: <height>, Start: (<xS>, <yS>), Finish: (<xF>, <yF>)
        Example:
         W: 9, H: 23, Start: (1, 12), Finish: (5, 1)
